title: Who will win the upcoming election for the United Kingdom's Labour Party?
preds:
That's it folks!
'Labour leadership hopeful Owen Smith, asked in an interview in the final hours of the campaign whether he would serve in a Jeremy Corbyn shadow cabinet, said: "I won't be serving in Jeremy's cabinet but I will do what I've always done which is be Labour, vote Labour, loyally serve this party, make sure that from the backbenches I continue to make the arguments I've made during this campaign." '
All reports are that Corbyn will win by a comfortable margin.
Corbyn has a hold on the party. Moderate labour MPs are going to be sacrificed just like Blue dog Dems and Mod GOP members. Labour is heading to the extremes.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

http://www.businessinsider.com/jeremy-corbyn-sadiq-khan-labour-leadership-election-2016-8 popular mayor - his statements could influence voters
Statements themselves are inflammatory (not the usual bland politico-speak), 
quite cringe-worthy if you're Corbyn. I would say this is less a statement endorsing Owen, and more an excoriation of voting for Corbyn
Pushing Smith's chance down in light on no significant changes.
polls remain firmly in favour of Corbyn, Smith is running out of time to realise a change
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Time is running out for the situation to change. Reduced smith's chances

The only public poll of the campaign shows Jeremy Corbyn gaining over 60% of the vote. Smith's dubious popularity and profile is unlikely to change any of this. Additionally, Corbyn's campaign has the infrastructure of Momentum to campaign effectively, while Smith has no equivalent ground campaign.
If they are going down in polls, they figure to have someone do it who will become a non-starter in another election. Labor will continue its divisions,

http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/owen-smiths-local-members-back-jeremy-corbyn-pontypridd_uk_57d182e1e4b0d45ff8715667 "Owen Smith’s own Labour constituency members are backing Jeremy Corbyn by a margin of two to one, according to new data seen by HuffPost UK. The figures, gathered by the Corbyn campaign, found that 64% of party members in Pontypridd will vote for the leader, and just 29% for their local MP.  Some 56% of Pontypridd CLP members responded to the straw poll, with 5% saying they were ‘undecided’ and 2% refusing to say.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I'm a bit skeptical of this poll because it was conducted by one of the candidates (Corbyn).
The polls give Corbyn a comfortable lead. He appears to connect with the party in a way Owen Smith does not. The opposition is the mainstream media and PLP has galvanised Corbyn's supporters.

Reiterate mid-August comment:  Facts & circumstances now  make increasingly clear, in the face of a) ONE  sided negative traditional media, b) status quo pundit/expert analysis including a   dogmatic & negative TWITTER audience, that c)  there is a v high probability Jeremy Corbyn  will win the Labor Party election.  There is also a common thread in the Corbyn Labor vote & BREXIT outcome. The political experts, media & pundentry remain excellent CONTRARIAN indicators when balanced against eventual election results. Importantly, their views are NOT to be dismissed. Rather, they continue to be quite useful to forecasting a good result when one provides weight (or counterweight as the case warrants ) to their historical track record on who they support.
Leads in last polls by 62-38%. A huge margin, as he has led all along. Betting odds also favour Corbyn heavily. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)_leadership_election,_2016
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Adjusted probability given the polls and given the lack of traction of Smith
The polls are hugely in favor of Mr. Corbyn.
http://www.crcconnection.com/2016/09/02/poll-boost-for-jeremy-corbyn-in-labour-leadership-battle.html This piece references a poll showing Corbyn with a 24 point lead over Smith.

Poll carried out by  YouGov shows clear win by Corbyn. "Corbyn secured 62 per cent of the vote - 24 points ahead of his rival and more than two points more than his own vote last year." [1]. It is interesting, however, the fact that many Labour supporters voted for Brexit was attributed partly to Corbyn's failure to convince Labour to vote for Remain. Moreover, although his leadership is being challenged by his MPs, he retains such a strong support by the party base.  Are there similarities with the Trump phenomenon - the public votes against to what it considers to be the wish (or will) of the establishment?  [1]http://www.theweek.co.uk/labour-leadership-election/74344/labour-leadership-election-what-the-latest-polls-and-odds-reveal

I think I over-reacted to the polling done by pro-Smith MPs earlier.  
http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/309604

I have underestimated the difference in Corbyn's popularity between Labour MP's and party members eligible to vote. His fellow MP's had the vote of no-confidence post Brexit but this is not shared by party members around Britain. The latest polls give mr Smith no chance and also the bookmakers give a Corbyn victory more than 85% chance. I move up but remain below polls and bookies.
First forecast. Might update it later but thus far i see no way for Owen Smith to gain more ground on Corbyn.
YouGov poll gives Corbyn a huge lead gotta up his chances. https://yougov.co.uk/news/2016/08/30/labour-leadership-election-corbyn-leads-smith-24/

http://www.oddschecker.com/politics/british-politics/labour-leadership-election Odds are rapidly shortening in favour of Corbyn. Several bookies now have him as 1/20, probably as a result of 
https://yougov.co.uk/news/2016/08/30/labour-leadership-election-corbyn-leads-smith-24/ (Thanks, @ChrisClark ).

OK, so I put Corbyn on 70% yesterday afternoon because there was uncertainty springing from the lack of polling. YouGov have released that polling this morning and Jeremy looks like he's going to smash it. Full results here: https://yougov.co.uk/news/2016/08/30/labour-leadership-election-corbyn-leads-smith-24/

http://www.theweek.co.uk/labour-leadership-election/74344/labour-leadership-election-polls-and-odds-mps-snub-corbyn "Bookmakers and pollsters have predicted a win for Jeremy Corbyn in the Labour leadership election, but new analysis of voters suggests it will be a much tighter race than previously predicted. "Saving Labour, an anti-Corbyn campaign group, claims the election will come down to just a few thousand votes. It predicts around 62 per cent of the registered supporters who paid £25 for a vote last month will back the Labour leader's rival, Owen Smith.
It also believes he has the support of 60 per cent of members who joined before the 2015 general election. "However, Corbyn is said to have the backing of two-thirds of the 150,000 people who joined the party between May 2015 and January 2016. "Nevertheless, Saving Labour says Smith has a slim majority of trade union-affiliated members – and ultimately could edge the race by around 4,000 votes. "The analysis will come as a surprise to many, who have seen Mr Corbyn attract huge crowds across the country in recent weeks," says the Daily Mirror.
. . . 
"Saving Labour's numbers are plausible - but they feel unlikely," says Stephen Bush at the New Statesman. He points out Smith would need "big wins among trade unionists and registered supporters, both of which went for Corbyn by large margins last time".
However, he concedes that if "last year’s £3ers were drawn from 'Old Labour in exile', it is possible this year's £25ers are 'New Labour in exile'".
. . . 
"The deadline for voters to choose between current leader Jeremy Corbyn and former work and pensions secretary Owen Smith is 21 September, with the winner announced three days later.   "In recent days, a number of senior Labour politicians – including Scottish Labour Party leader Kezia Dugdale and London Mayor Sadiq Kahn – have come out in support of Smith, arguing that a party led by Corbyn would have no chance of winning the next general election. "Most commentators – and bookies – predict Corbyn will be announced the winner at a special conference in Liverpool next month. "Few believe Corbyn's soft-left challenger will prevail," says the New Statesmen.

There really has been no polling of Labour's "selectorate" since the race began in earnest. The assumption of another Corbyn victory is based on little real analysis. Just as the Corbyn phenomenon crept up almost entirely unnoticed by the mainstream press, I think it is fair to suggest that Labour members and registered supporters might turn towards another, electable alternative now that Corbyn has served his purpose by moving the entire party further leftwards.
Jeremy Corbyn is hands-down the favourite with members 'on the ground' however the party hierarchy is doing all in its power to purge Corbyn supporters.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
The present alignment and strength of factions within the Labour Party (Trade Unions, parliamentary party, individuals and general mood) make it very improbable for  Owen Smith to win.

Another wee adjustment called for due to the attacks from the Corbyn camp on the Scottish leader Kezia Dugdale.  The Corbyn camp must be pretty confident of victory if they are prepared to brief against the leadership north of the border. http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/14709297.Labour_big_guns_turn_on_Dugdale/

We seem to be living an a era of the uber-protest vote, where enthusiasts vote for a dream (their dream, maybe our nightmare) candidate who has no possibility of actually doing whatever they say they will do. Corbyn, Trump, Brexit all fall into this category). At some point voters will presumably switch to candidates that have policies that have some chance of being carried out, but this will probably not happen in the next 4 weeks.
Looks like we have a winner
The electorate for Labour and Corbyn have become co-dependent.
NEC purging Corbyn supporters doubt they can make huge dent but shaved a few points of Corbyn's lead.
It is difficult for me to imagine what would change the voting pattern from when Jeremy Corbyn was elected leader.

Having a great deal of difficulty believing anything but a Corbyn win is likely. However this piece in today's Mirror http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/could-labour-leadership-race-closer-8696934#ICID=sharebar_twitter and the barrage of anti Corbyn press forces an adjustment.
Corbyn will win. If after that he will be allowed to continue as labour leader is another question.

http://www.oddschecker.com/politics/british-politics/labour-leadership-election Bookmakers are offering odds of between 1/7 and 1/9 on Corbyn, and between 9/2 and 11/2 on Smith. Corbyn's image may suffer further as a result of his claim (of having to sit on the floor of  a "ram-packed" train) being convincingly refuted by Virgin Trains. I still think he's going to win, though.
http://www.oddschecker.com/tips/politics/20160823-corbyns-leadership-campaign-could-be-derailed-by-traingate

https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/1661719/labours-owen-smith-branded-a-disgrace-over-vow-to-block-brexit-unless-theresa-may-calls-second-referendum/ My take:  Owen Smith has declared that under his leadership (if elected) Labor would vote for another referendum on the actual TERMS of Brexit.  This does not seem to be winning him any votes!

Corbyn is 1.16 (an 86% chance) with Smith 7.00. Corbyn is also  to win 65-70% of the vote. That is an incredibly large margin. https://betting.betfair.com/politics/uk-politics/uk-politics-betting-and-latest-odds-labour-leadership-contest-sunday-august-21-2016-210816-204.html
Following @Anneinak and @Khalid, although I still think Corbyn will win

At 98% I've been higher than bookmakers and feeling uneasy about it, especially after Sadiq Khan came out in Owen's support. Now news of significant shifts in private constituency polls as reported by @Anneinak require a downward adjustment. I'll have to follow polls more closely from now on.

http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/owen-smith-supporters-say-he-is-catching-up-with-jeremy-corbyn_uk_57b70843e4b042aee74b53aa "Owen Smith is catching up in the race to be Labour leader in some constituencies, according to a series of polls conducted by Smith-supporting MPs. "Despite lagging well behind Jeremy Corbyn in other polls, Smith backers say he has pulled ahead in various parts of Britain in the last two weeks. "Corbyn has been widely tipped to win the Labour leadership election in a landslide. Betfair give Smith a 12% of winning; Corbyn has gained 285 constituency party nominations, while Smith is on just 53.  However some Labour MPs think the race is a great deal closer.  “All the Parliamentary Labour party private polling running into 1000’s shows a much tighter race”, says Graham Jones, Labour MP for Hyndburn, where, he says, the two contenders are neck and neck. “Much tighter. I don’t know a constituency... being polled where Corbyn is in front. At best he’s neck and neck or Smith has a 20% lead.” “There is a lot of switching from Jeremy to Owen. Or Jeremy to don’t know”, says Andy Slaughter, Labour MP for Hammersmith. According to his poll of  members in his constituency ― which, he says, took in 70% of them ― Smith is polling at 59%, Corbyn at 26%, and those who are undecided at 15%.  "Ben Bradshaw, Labour’s MP for Exeter, says a curve towards Smith has emerged in the last two weeks. “I have become much more optimistic following phone canvassing of members in the last 10 days”, he says.
. . . 
"Mark Jackson, a volunteer conducting research for Labour in Brighton and Hove, says he sees a recent crop of “undecideds” “dropping and breaking towards Owen”. Brighton is a traditionally left wing stronghold, which might be expected to strongly favour Corbyn. But, Jackson says, “it has got relatively close between Jeremy and Owen recently”. “There is a not insignificant group who voted for Jeremy last time and are not planning to vote for him this time. I think it is certainly not going to be a complete landslide.” "People are changing sides, he says, because “they like Jeremy’s politics but in the last ten or eleven months in terms of practical leadership, they think he has not done well. The second broad theme is dissatisfaction from people on the EU referendum and the campaign for that”. "According to Bradshaw, the most common reason given by Labour members in Exeter who favour Smith is “electability”. “The second is unity. Those two things are connected. The third, quite a way behind, is Brexit”, he says.  "Corbyn’s office remains confident of victory, and private polling has proved unreliable in the past. But Labour MPs argue that this time their research is based on a wider sample of Labour members than other polls. “I completely accept that these findings might be exceptional - but it’s quite a high level of sampling”, says Bradshaw. “I predicted previous Labour leaderships correctly based on my canvassing.” "Jones reckons Smith supporters have only emerged in recent days. “The hard to contacts are solid Smith and the easy to contacts are solid Corbyn”, he says.  "Saving Labour, a pro-Smith group, recently said it has recruited 70,000 of 140,000 of Labour’s registered supporters, who, it says, are likely to vote for Smith.
~~~~~~~
COMMENTS:  
The averages of the 8 polls from specific constituencies cited in this article are:  Smith 52%, Corbyn 36%, undecided 12%.  I wonder about all the other constituencies! It certainly seems that the Smith campaign is gaining momentum.  The Mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, has strongly endorsed Smith, an endorsement that is likely to carry significant weight. I'll be watching for other polls . . .
Sadiq Khan's support for Owen will make a diffrence to the vote, minimal not enough to stop Corbyn winning  so slight adjustment.

Sadiq Khan, the (Labor) Mayor of London, and arguably the most popular elected Labor leader, has declared his support for Owen Smith.  I think Khan's endorsement will have significant impact.  Reducing my pro-Corbyn forecast to 66%
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
A majority of labour lost confidence in Corbyn after the Brexit vote. Although he did not step down after losing a vote of confidence many prominent party members do not support Mr Corbyn.
Strong support from members for Corbyn. Latest information limiting potential for voting to exisiting members only will work in favour of Corbyn.
Moving from 99-1 to 100-0. Not sure why I didn't choose 100 originally.

The voting is rigged by the Labour Party system that gives votes to party members and the unions that outweigh the votes from MPs. The parliamentary party seems out of step from the membership and we're more likely to see MPs defect to form a modern labour party rather than accept Corbyn's re-epection as leader
Owen Smith has very low press coverage. The 'weapons' the Labour party can use against Jeremy Cornyn have already been used and failed to be effective. If anything they have strengthened JC position.
The Labour Party members appear to be firmly behind the incumbent with many upset by the behaviour of rebel Labour MPs, it seems there is little prospect of a change.

I believe that Jeremy Corbyn retains the support of most of the party membership, and unless the rules are changed he will win the leadership election - hence the 80/15 split in his favour. There is an outside chance that the split between the national and Westminster parties will result in some unforseen development - hence the 5% for None of the above.
Even with the High Court judgement on new members going against him (as both sides seem to agree), he still has  a solid base in the party.

"Deep Listen, a project that will use natural language processing to recognise the nuances of positive and negative statements, in an attempt to correctly predict the next leader of the Labour Party, three days before it is announced in September this year."
http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/businessreview/2016/08/18/businesses-can-no-longer-ignore-social-media-sentiment-analysis/
http://deeplisten.io/ As stated elsewhere, I am truly interested in sentiment analysis, particularly "adjective analysis." Deep Listen, it appears, will, at least in this instance, be delivering a one-off prediction, late in the game. I'd be interested in learning if anyone is aware of anybody that is currently tracking sentiment (of whatever type, adjective analysis or no) on a continuous, on-going basis (rather than one off predictions). Any links to such projects would be appreciated. A focus on future events would be preferable, but beggars can't be choosers, so I'd appreciate  links that just track sentiments (or attitudes, or moods?) on current states of some population on a historical basis as well. Update#1: Upon reflection, I'd also like to mention that I have a keen interest in the "transitivity of sentiments," and sentiment ontology generally. Update#2: "At issue is the fundamental difference between information and meaning."
https://hbr.org/2016/08/to-get-more-out-of-social-media-think-like-an-anthropologist?curator=MediaREDEF

No change to forecast & irrelevant for scoring purposes. However, nonetheless interesting 50 second piece from BBC:  Date: 18. August 2016 um 15:20:02 MESZ Subject: BBC Debate: Corbyn vs Owens Comment:
Says a lot.  Must have been an extremely uncomfortable moment for Mr.Owens.  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1r1D-qvwMKI&sns=em
Owen Smith has just stated we should get round the table with ISIS British Press will run with this and it will undermine his position further. Only 1% lower but very low chance to begin with.

The balance of probability suggests Corbyn will win comfortably. However, some of the votes from unions have been more mixed, plus there is a chance of a "shy Smith voter" effect, as Corbyn's vociferous supporters seem to make people fear challenging his "cult" status openly. The appeals-court exclusion of 100,000+ Labour party members who joined after the cut-off date may also limit the potential for a JC landslide & increase the (smallish) chances of an upset
winning the endorsements from 84% of local parties and being a heavy favorite at multiple odds sites, it would be a huge upset if Corbyn lost

http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/08/15/the-numbers-dont-lie-splitting-would-be-catastrophic-for-labour/ " A YouGov poll of Labour members for the Times in mid-July has him winning 56-34 over the (then hypothetical) challenger Owen Smith. Even allowing for polling error, that points to a clear victory."

Jeremy Corbyn has won local party nominations by a landslide in the Labour leadership contest, with 84% of constituency nominations at the final count. The Labour leader won the support of 285 constituency Labour parties (CLPs), with his rival, Owen Smith, taking just 53 nominations.
http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/aug/15/jeremy-corbyn-wins-backing-84-per-cent-local-labour-parties

Corbyn has support of 84% of local labor parties:
http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/aug/15/jeremy-corbyn-wins-backing-84-per-cent-local-labour-parties
Jc has broad support in the party and especially the new members, new membership have been massive

Most new members are Corbyn supporters. The Labour NEC now has a majority who back Corbyn and opportunities to overturn the disenfranchisement of 130,000 new members. The recent appeal court judgement which upheld the NEC's right to rewrite the rules as it sees fit will now work in favour of Corbyn supporting rule changes. It will be very difficult for Smith's supporters to make a case against any new rules. http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/13/labour-leadership-coup-jeremy-corbyn-allies-hope-to-water-down-m/
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/polls-show-jeremy-corbyn-cruising-8626072 "The exclusive survey for the Sunday Mirror reveals that Mr Corbyn enjoys a lead of 22 points over Owen Smith in the race to be leader . . . "

Membership has been overtaken by extreme left - not representative of voters or of MPs. Too bad for a party with a legacy of intellectual honesty and with Tony Blair, electability, credibility and part of the mainstream.

Waiting on new polls.... The polls may have trouble identifying those eligible to vote from those that are not eligible. ...... Corbyn may make one last appeal on the voter eligibility case, 130,000 votes again at risk.

UP 1% from 98 to 99%.
@dominich a well structured argument supportive of his position. well done.

NEC appeals and wins the right to restrict voting in leadership contest.
http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-37057589

Really, only if Corbyn is run over by a bus will he not win this poll, for several reasons. (a) New membership. being strongly pro-Corbyn  (And the current dispute over voting rights of members who joined in the previous six months may not have major impact here, as this applies to those who joined in the second half of 2015 as much as in the first half of 2016)  The various sects around him - notably those which operate under the name "Momentum" (legal name of one section: "Jeremy for Labour") have enthused many formerly "non-political" (or inactive far-left, or former Greens) to join the Labour Party, specifically to endorse what are regarded as Corbyn's worldview. The vast increase in party membership over the past year has been largely of these people - and it is largely true that such far-left viewpoints have largely lacked parliamentary representation in UK. It is highly probable that the expansion in Labour Party membership in the past year or so has been in large measure out of support for Corbyn, One anecdotal example of this (in one seat in which Labour increased their share of the vote, at the expense of the Greens) is this email, from the time of last year's leadership contest, from what was then my local farmers' market (in a constituency entirely unrepresentative of the UK populace overall, but fairly representative of those supporting Corbyn) :  " The origins of democracy can be seen in the markets (agoras) of Greece and
later the forums of Rome. We believe our market has a social function beyond food and consumption. As such, you will find a stall from *'Oxford for Corbyn*' at this week's market promoting Jeremy Corbyn MP's campaign
for leader of the Labour Party, which has sparked such tremendous debate across the country. Whilst we believe our market itself should remain apolitical, we are excited to make room for politics, discussions and
campaigns.".  (Needless to say, no stalls for any other leadership contenders' manifested themselves) 2. Constituency Labour Party votes.
The recent elections to Labour's National Executive Committee were a triumph for those allied to Corbyn http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/aug/08/labour-must-allow-all-members-leadership-vote-court-rules  "Results of the NEC elections showed that the six members elected to represent constituency Labour parties were Corbyn backers, while his critics, including current member Johanna Baxter, who recently complained about bullying in the party, and the comedian Eddie Izzard lost out." Moreover, the number of constituency parties backing Corbyn is far greater than those backing Smith.
http://labourlist.org/2016/07/which-constituencies-have-had-confidence-votes-in-jeremy-corbyns-leadership/
(This is purely symbolic, as the voting comprises individual members, but may also be indicative of the mood within the party).   But even in his native Wales only one constituency party has backed Smith.... 3). Owen Smith. He is an obscure figure (even more obscure than Corbyn was in his 32 years as a backbencher),  - almost completely unknown with the wider public, and even much of the paarty membership, but,  more importantly, has little substantive to distinguish himself from Corbyn. His policy proposals seem to be being laid out on a pitch that Corbyn has laid out - firmly to the (far) left, albeit with less overt or evident connections to extremists or policies that the general populace might be expected to regard as absurd (eg quasi-pacifism.)  Really all the momentum (please excuse the pun) is on Corbyn's side here. .The fact that his victory may well spell the end of the Labour Party (as Corbyn's unpopularity with both Labour MPs and the wider electorate show) seems irrevelvant to the very curious (and somewhat vicious) cult around him.
Jeremy Corbyn won a landslide victory with the party membership, nothing has changed in his support from the membership loyalty
http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/08/11/jeremy-corbyns-fans-jeer-owen-smith-on-labours-darkest-day-liter/ "Mr Smith is seen as a safer bet against Mr Corbyn"
JC has the support of the vast majority of voting party members, therefore Owen Smith can't win.

Because I am Anneinak (see @BG1 http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/300781) I am struggling with this question.  (Smile). I am a huge admirer of  @AndrewSabisky, who says Corbyn has it, 99%.
 http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/300568 But my own research doesn't support such a strong forecast.  See http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/300200 and http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/300435. And then there's the betting pools and odds (http://www.theweek.co.uk/labour-leadership-election/74344/labour-leadership-election-odds-and-polls-can-corbyn-win), that @BG1 has shared, which everybody in the world seems to understand but me. The consensus has left me behind in the dust, and I think it would be foolish to not follow AndrewSabisky & BG1, but I am not knowledgeable enough to do so on anything other than blind faith.  Oh ye of little faith, Anneinak, for deciding to stay put for now.  Maybe this evening's google search will turn up something that will give me "faith".

Comment:
CAN'T help myself. After the BREXIT Q, having noticed this Q tonight,  I'll admit to:
a) being a glutton for punishment;  
b) attempting to find justification/logic or, c)none of the above, 
 to a begin this process w/ a forecast of 98% chance Jeremy Corybn will win upcoming election for UK's Labor Party 
Date: 11. August 2016 um 13:32:33 MESZ
1.http://www.theweek.co.uk/labour-leadership-election/74344/labour-leadership-election-odds-and-polls-can-corbyn-win;  2. 	Mike Smithson (@MSmithsonPB)
11.08.16, 13:15
Smith now a 12% chance on Betfair to beat Corbyn. Last week he was rated by Betfair punters as a 6% one. pic.twitter.com/6XSr7gdx8i YET...
3.
Subject: Corbyn: Zero Chance of leading Labor to Outright Majority in UK http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/jeremy-corbyn-has-0-chance-of-leading-labour-to-outright-majority-electoral-calculus-says_uk_57a985cbe4b07285e131da02 P.S. also "influenced" by @AndrewSabisky b/c he is an Englishman & @Anneinak b/c she is Anneinak !

nope, the consensus is wrong, & Smith isn't particularly close to 9% to win this. To be honest a more interesting question would be around Corbyn's margin of victory.  Base rates here are not relevant because the demographic composition of the Labour Party membership has changed enormously over the past few years, so the electorate that voted in Smith, Blair, and Ed Miliband bares little resemblance to the electorate that voted in Corbyn. Even that last electorate has changed substantially since the last leadership race. A huge flood of communists, Greens, Socialists, & other hard-leftists have entered the party, many of whom have never voted Labour before, specifically in order to back to Corbyn. Smith is a dead duck.

Labour's chance of winning a general election under Corbyn's leadership does not look so strong. The latest voting intention figures from YouGov show the Conservatives on 42 per cent, with Labour trailing behind on 28 per cent.What are Corbyn's odds? Some bookmakers are offering odds as short as 1/20 on Corbyn remaining as leader, while Smith has odds of around 8/1.
http://www.theweek.co.uk/labour-leadership-election/74344/labour-leadership-election-odds-and-polls-can-corbyn-win
for my reasons, see my post and additional comment at http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/300200

Pro Corbyn:  (see  http://www.politico.eu/article/jeremy-corbyn-labour-leader-copies-the-bernie-sanders-playbook-socialist-campaign-momentum/) -He is running a very lean, smart, efficient grass-roots campaign that sounds to be modeled after Sanders' "movement politics".  "“Sanders went from 3 percent in the polls to coming damn close to winning the Democratic presidential nomination and has changed the party in the process. Obama did something similar. There’s no doubt that with the right message and the right leadership, movement politics can reach and persuade many more voters than the traditional toolkit of speeches, voter ID, door knocking and billboards, that type of thing.”    -his supporters estimate that 25,000 people have attended around 40 pro-Corbyn campaign rallies, even though the Labour leader has only been at a handful of them. . . an ". . .organizer filmed the queue of supporters waiting outside to hear Corbyn speak. The video was uploaded onto Facebook nine minutes later and seen 250,000 times within 15 minutes." -He's perceived as the front-runner:  "Mr Corbyn is set to receive another huge mandate from the Labour selectorate next month . . "  http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/08/10/only-electoral-humiliation-can-save-the-labour-party-now/ -"further the party falls behind the Conservatives in the polls under Mr Corbyn . . .  the less appetite there seems to be to depose him. . . . the problem Owen Smith faces is that Labour members are not convinced the party can win a general election with him leading it either. And if you are going to lose anyway, why not do so with a supposed “man of principle” at the helm? http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/08/10/only-electoral-humiliation-can-save-the-labour-party-now/ -has the support of the Communication Workers Union, which has 200,000 members,  ASLEF, the train drivers' union, and Ucatt, construction workers' union Pro Smith:
-Smith is backed by the vast majority of Labor MPs Pro None of the above:

If the selection was left to the party elites I would say Owen overwhelmingly, however, the rank and file call this shot and they have not abandoned Corbyn.   He is a populist in a time when that is what many feel is needed.
The Labor party has spent too much time trying to be a centralist party and that is not what the active members of the party want.  It has not brought them back to power and so it is a disappointing strategy to the party faithful.
